title: Coordinate Plane Explorer
description: An interactive MicroSim that helps students understand the coordinate plane structure, including quadrants, axes, origin, and point location through hands-on exploration and quiz mode.
subject: Mathematics
prerequisites: Understanding of positive and negative numbers
Ability to read and write ordered pairs
learningObjectives: Identify and label the x-axis, y-axis, and origin on a coordinate plane
Understand the structure and numbering of the four quadrants
Plot points accurately using ordered pairs (x, y)
Determine which quadrant contains a given point
Recognize the sign patterns for coordinates in each quadrant
Use coordinates to describe the location of points on a plane
educationalStandards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.NS.C.6 - Understand rational numbers as points on the number line and in the coordinate plane
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.NS.C.8 - Solve problems by graphing points in all four quadrants
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.G.A.3 - Draw polygons in the coordinate plane
author: MicroSim Development Team

controls.label: Point
controls.description: Drag the red point anywhere on the coordinate plane to explore different coordinate positions

controls.label: Enter x
controls.description: Input field to enter the x-coordinate directly

controls.label: Enter y
controls.description: Input field to enter the y-coordinate directly

controls.label: Plot
controls.description: Plot the point at the coordinates entered in the input fields

controls.label: Random Point
controls.description: Generate and plot a random point on the coordinate plane

controls.label: Quiz Mode
controls.description: Toggle quiz mode where students are challenged to plot given coordinates

controls.label: Check Answer
controls.description: Check if the plotted point matches the quiz target (only visible in quiz mode)

controls.label: Quadrant Shading
controls.description: Toggle color-coded shading of the four quadrants

controls.label: Grid Lines
controls.description: Toggle visibility of grid lines for easier point placement

controls.label: Reference Lines
controls.description: Toggle dotted lines from the point to both axes

visualElements: Coordinate grid from -10 to 10 on both axes
Bold axis lines (x-axis and y-axis)
Origin marked with dot and (0, 0) label
Quadrant labels (I, II, III, IV) in Roman numerals
Color-coded quadrant shading (I: light blue, II: light green, III: light yellow, IV: light pink)
Draggable red point with shadow effect
Dotted reference lines from point to axes
Real-time coordinate display with color coding
Quadrant identification display
interactiveFeatures: Drag point to any location on the plane
Smooth animations when plotting new points
Direct coordinate entry via input fields
assessmentOpportunities: Quiz mode tracks correct vs. total attempts
Immediate feedback on coordinate plotting accuracy
Hints provided when answers are incorrect (which coordinate needs adjustment)
Observable student exploration patterns
Exit ticket: Successfully plot 3 points in quiz mode

accessibility.screenReader: Includes describe() function for screen reader support
accessibility.colorBlindSafe: Uses high contrast colors and multiple visual cues beyond color

commonMisconceptions.remedy: Color-coded display always shows x first; mnemonic 'x before y in alphabet'
Quadrant shading visually shows negative regions; incremental practice

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Points on axes belong to quadrants
commonMisconceptions.remedy: Clear 'On x-axis' or 'On y-axis' messages; discussion of quadrant definitions

extensionActivities: Plot points to create geometric shapes

technologyRequirements.devices: Desktop, laptop, tablet (700px width minimum recommended)

cognitiveLoadConsiderations.intrinsic: Coordinate system with four quadrants and signed numbers
cognitiveLoadConsiderations.extraneous: Minimized through clean interface and optional visual aids
cognitiveLoadConsiderations.germane: Focused on coordinate relationships and spatial reasoning

differentiationStrategies: Quadrant shading can be toggled for visual learners
Grid lines assist students who need more structure
Reference lines show explicit connections to axes
Quiz mode provides practice with immediate feedback
Random point generator offers unlimited practice opportunities

title: Expression Parts Explorer
description: An interactive educational MicroSim that helps students identify and understand the different parts of algebraic expressions including coefficients, variables, constants, and terms through color-coding and interactive exploration.
subject: Mathematics - Algebra
creator: Generated with Claude Code
prerequisites: Basic understanding of numbers and arithmetic operations
Familiarity with the concept of variables in algebra
learningObjectives: Identify coefficients, variables, constants, and operations in algebraic expressions
Distinguish between different types of terms in multi-term expressions
Analyze the structure of algebraic expressions of varying complexity
Apply understanding to classify expression parts independently
accessibility: Screen reader support via describe() function

controls.name: New Expression
controls.description: Generates a new random algebraic expression based on the selected complexity level

controls.name: Quiz Mode
controls.description: Toggles quiz mode where users can click on parts to test their understanding without color hints

controls.name: Complexity Level
controls.description: Controls the complexity of generated expressions: Simple (2-3 terms), Medium (3-5 terms with exponents), Complex (4-6 terms with exponents)

controls.name: Show Coefficients
controls.description: Toggles color highlighting of coefficients in blue

controls.name: Show Variables
controls.description: Toggles color highlighting of variables in green

controls.name: Show Constants
controls.description: Toggles color highlighting of constants in orange

controls.name: Highlight Terms
controls.description: Toggles visual highlighting of individual terms in the expression

parameters.name: Complexity
parameters.description: Determines the number of terms, use of exponents, and coefficient ranges

expressionGeneration.Medium: 3-5 terms, may include exponents up to ^3, coefficients 1-20

educationalStandards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.EE.A.2 - Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.EE.A.1 - Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions

dublinCore.title: Integer Operations on the Number Line
creator: Dan McCreary
ChatGPT (GPT-5)
subject: Mathematics
Integers
Number Line
Arithmetic
dublinCore.description: An interactive p5.js simulation that visualizes integer addition and subtraction as movements on a horizontal number line. Users can click buttons to add or subtract values from -10 to +10, observing animated arrows and a cumulative equation.

learningObjectives: Visualize integer addition as movement to the right on a number line.
Visualize integer subtraction as movement to the left on a number line.
Interpret a cumulative arithmetic expression such as 0 + 3 - 2 + 4 = 5.
prerequisites: Understanding of positive and negative numbers

accessibility.screenReaderScript: Simulation that shows integer addition and subtraction as movement along a horizontal number line from -10 to +10. Blue circle shows current value, green arrows for addition, red arrows for subtraction.

controls.label: Add Buttons
controls.description: Adds positive integers (1–5) to the current position

controls.label: Subtract Buttons
controls.description: Subtracts positive integers (1–5) from the current position

controls.label: Reset
controls.description: Resets the simulation back to zero

visualElements.description: Horizontal number line from -10 to +10 with labeled tick marks
Green and red arrows animate integer addition and subtraction.

model.description: Integer arithmetic model representing cumulative addition and subtraction operations visualized as movements along a number line.
assumptions: Each operation changes the position by an integer step between -5 and +5.
Position range is clamped between -10 and +10.
limitations: Only supports integer values
Fixed range from -10 to +10

variables.name: currentPosition
variables.description: Current integer value on the number line

variables.name: equationParts
variables.description: String representation of the sequence of operations

events.name: operationPerformed
events.description: User clicked an Add or Subtract button

assessmentQuestions.question: If you start at -2 and add 4, what is your new position?
Explain why subtraction moves left on the number line.

extensions: Add sliders for variable step sizes
Include random problem generator for practice

title: Prime Factorization Tree Builder
description: Interactive tool for building factor trees to find prime factorization of composite numbers through step-by-step visual construction.
subject: Mathematics
learningObjectives: Build factor trees to decompose composite numbers into prime factors
Identify and distinguish between prime and composite numbers
Understand that prime factorization is unique for each number (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic)
Apply divisibility rules to find factors efficiently
Express numbers in prime factorization form using exponential notation
bloomLevels: Remember: Recall prime numbers and divisibility rules
Understand: Explain the relationship between factors and prime factorization
Apply: Use divisibility rules to factor numbers systematically
Analyze: Compare different factorization paths leading to same result
Evaluate: Verify completeness and correctness of factorization
Create: Build complete factor trees for any composite number
prerequisites: Familiarity with prime and composite numbers
author: Claude (Anthropic AI)

controls.numberInput: Enter a number between 4 and 200 to factor
controls.randomNumber: Generate a random composite number at selected difficulty
controls.giveHint: Highlight a composite number and suggest divisibility rule
controls.showAnswer: Display the complete factorization tree with all prime factors
controls.clickNode: Click on blue (composite) nodes to enter two factors
controls.submitFactors: Validate and add factors to the tree

visualElements.edges: Lines connecting parent numbers to their factors
visualElements.primeList: Reference list of prime numbers up to 47
visualElements.divisibilityRules: Quick reference for divisibility by 2, 3, and 5

features: Show answer feature for complete factorization
pedagogicalApproach: Scaffolding through hints and reference materials
assessmentOpportunities: Predict prime factorization before building tree
Explain why different trees yield same factorization
Factor numbers with varying complexity
Identify patterns in factorizations
Apply divisibility rules efficiently
Compare factorization strategies
commonMisconceptions: Using 1 as a factor (prevented by validation)
Stopping factorization before reaching primes (visual feedback)
Entering incorrect factors (shake animation feedback)
Confusion about prime vs composite (color coding)
extensions: Compare different factorization paths for same number
Find GCF and LCM using prime factorizations
Explore perfect squares and their symmetric trees
Apply to finding square roots of perfect squares

technicalDetails.animations: shake on error, celebration on completion
technicalDetails.dataStructure: tree represented as nodes and edges

title: Koch Fractal
creator: Generated with Claude Code
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Fractals
Computer Science
description: An interactive visualization demonstrating the iterative construction of the Koch curve, a classic fractal with self-similar patterns at every scale. Students can adjust the recursion level from 0 to 6 to observe how simple iterative rules create complex fractal patterns.

learningObjectives: Understand how simple iterative rules can create complex patterns
Explore the concept of self-similarity in fractals
Observe how mathematical infinity can be approached through finite iterations
Connect geometric transformations with fractal generation
Calculate fractal dimensions and understand dimensions beyond integers
prerequisites: Basic understanding of line segments and geometric transformations
Familiarity with the concept of iteration
Knowledge of equilateral triangles (helpful but not required)

controls.name: recursionSlider
controls.label: Recursion Level
controls.purpose: Controls the number of iterations in the Koch curve construction. Level 0 shows a straight line, while higher levels show increasingly complex fractal patterns.

variables: baselineY: Vertical position of the fractal baseline
canvasWidth: Responsive width of the drawing canvas
model.algorithm: Recursive Koch curve generation using geometric transformation
model.description: At each recursion level, every line segment is divided into three equal parts, and the middle third is replaced with two sides of an equilateral triangle. This process creates a self-similar fractal pattern.
equations: Length at level n: (4/3)^n × original length
Number of segments at level n: 4^n
assumptions: The fractal is displayed as a 2D projection
Maximum recursion level is limited to 6 for performance
Discrete rendering approximates the theoretical continuous curve
limitations: Does not show the full Koch snowflake (three curves arranged in a triangle)
Does not animate the iterative construction process
Performance may decrease at high recursion levels on slower devices

assessmentOpportunities: Pattern recognition at different recursion levels
Mathematical calculation of length and segments
Understanding of fractal dimension concept
Connection to real-world fractal examples
commonMisconceptions: Believing the curve will eventually smooth out
Thinking infinite length means infinite area
Confusion between recursion level and fractal dimension

subject: Mathematics

Recursion
Computer Science
dublin_core.description: An interactive visualization of the Sierpinski triangle fractal demonstrating recursive subdivision and self-similar patterns. Students can adjust the recursion depth from 0 to 7 levels to explore how simple rules create complex fractal patterns.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of recursive subdivision in geometry
Analyze how fractals exhibit self-similarity at different scales
Explore the relationship between recursion depth and pattern complexity
Evaluate how mathematical infinity appears in finite visualizations
Calculate exponential growth in triangle counts (3^n)
prerequisites: Basic understanding of triangles and geometric shapes

controls.label: Recursion Depth
controls.description: Controls the number of recursive subdivisions in the Sierpinski triangle pattern

parameters.name: currentDepth
parameters.purpose: Determines how many levels of recursion to apply when drawing the fractal

displays.label: Triangles
displays.description: Shows total number of triangles drawn (3^depth)

key_variables: recursionDepth - Number of recursive subdivisions to perform
vertices - Coordinates of triangle vertices for each recursion level
algorithm: - Create 4 smaller triangles from these midpoints
- Draw only the 3 outer triangles (skip center)
- Recursively apply to each of the 3 triangles
equations: Triangle count = 3^n where n is recursion depth
Total area approaches 0 as n approaches infinity
assumptions: Perfect geometric precision in subdivision
Equilateral starting triangle
Infinite recursion not practically achievable (limited to depth 7)
limitations: Performance degrades beyond depth 7 due to exponential triangle count
Does not show the mathematical properties of infinite recursion
Visual resolution limits ability to see very small triangles at high depths

microsim.title: Cognitive Load Visualizer
microsim.description: Interactive visualization demonstrating the three types of cognitive load (intrinsic, extraneous, and germane) and their impact on working memory capacity. Users can adjust sliders to see how different load combinations affect learning effectiveness and explore optimal instructional design configurations.
microsim.subject: Educational Psychology
learning_objectives: Identify and distinguish between the three types of cognitive load
Explain how each type of cognitive load affects learning outcomes
Recognize when total cognitive load exceeds working memory capacity
Apply cognitive load principles to evaluate instructional design
Design learning materials that optimize cognitive load
prerequisites: Basic understanding of how learning works
microsim.author: Intelligent Textbooks Project

controls.name: Intrinsic Load
controls.description: Adjust the inherent difficulty of the content being learned

controls.name: Extraneous Load
controls.description: Adjust the mental effort wasted on poor instructional design

controls.name: Germane Load
controls.description: Adjust the mental effort devoted to learning processes

controls.name: Good Design Example
controls.description: Load an example showing optimal cognitive load balance

controls.name: Bad Design Example
controls.description: Load an example showing cognitive overload

controls.name: Reset to Default
controls.description: Return all sliders to their default values

feedback_mechanisms: Color changes (blue/orange/red) based on load level

assessment_suggestions: Ask students to identify which type of load each design element creates
Have students calculate total load from given scenarios
Request redesign of high-load materials to reduce extraneous load
Ask students to justify load estimates for specific learning materials
Have students create load profiles for different learner expertise levels
extension_activities: Analyze real textbooks or courses for cognitive load issues
Create before/after designs showing load reduction
Research how expertise changes intrinsic load
Design a study to measure cognitive load in learners
Apply multimedia learning principles to reduce extraneous load

theoretical_foundation.developers: John Sweller, Paul Chandler, Fred Paas
key_principles: Working memory has limited capacity (typically 4-7 chunks)
Long-term memory has virtually unlimited capacity
Learning requires transferring information from working to long-term memory
Cognitive load is additive across all three types
Effective design manages all three types of load
research_support: Meta-analyses show effect sizes of 0.4-1.0 for load reduction
Split-attention effect consistently demonstrates extraneous load impact
Worked example effect shows intrinsic load management
Expertise reversal effect demonstrates load relativity

common_misconceptions: More information is always better (ignores capacity limits)
Attractive design is more important than clear design (adds extraneous load)
All cognitive effort is productive (ignores extraneous load)
Content difficulty can't be managed (ignores chunking strategies)

accessibility.described_content: Interactive cognitive load visualizer with three adjustable load types and a capacity meter showing when working memory is overloaded

All elements are interconnected and interdependent
Designers can start at any point based on project needs
Continuous revision of elements as information emerges

element_2.name: Learner Characteristics

key_questions: What prior knowledge do learners have?

element_3.name: Task Analysis

key_questions: What specific content must be covered?
What skills need to be developed?

element_4.name: Instructional Objectives
key_questions: What will learners be able to do after instruction?

element_5.name: Content Sequencing
element_5.description: Arrange content in logical, effective order
key_questions: In what order should concepts be taught?

element_6.name: Instructional Strategies
element_6.description: Design teaching methods and learning activities
key_questions: What teaching methods will be most effective?
How will learners engage with content?

element_7.name: Instructional Delivery
element_7.description: Plan how instruction will be delivered
key_questions: What delivery format is most appropriate?

element_8.name: Evaluation Instruments
key_questions: What evaluation methods align with objectives?

element_9.name: Support Services
key_questions: What budget and timeline constraints exist?

model_characteristics.iteration: Continuous revision of any element at any time

vs_sam.kemp_advantage: Holistic view of all factors simultaneously

challenges: Can feel less structured than ADDIE
Requires discipline to address all elements
May confuse stakeholders expecting linear process
Easy to neglect elements due to flexibility
success_factors: Regular reviews of all nine elements

Explain how SAM differs from traditional ADDIE approach
Understand the value of rapid prototyping and iteration
Recognize how product quality improves through successive iterations
Apply SAM principles to real instructional design projects

controls.description: Manually advance to the next phase in the SAM process

controls.description: Return to the beginning of the SAM process

controls.description: Control how fast the iterations progress in auto-play mode

visual_representations: Spiral path visualization showing iterative cycles

assessment_suggestions: Ask students to compare SAM and ADDIE for a specific project scenario
Have students identify which phase specific activities belong to
Request students to explain when to use SAM vs. ADDIE
Ask students to describe how quality improves through iterations
Have students plan a SAM project with specific iteration goals
extension_activities: Design a Savvy Start workshop agenda for a real project
Create rapid prototypes using paper or digital tools
Analyze a failed project and propose how SAM could have helped
Compare time and cost estimates for ADDIE vs. SAM approaches
Interview practitioners about their experiences with SAM

key_principles: Test early and often with real learners
Embrace change as part of the process

prototyping.sam: Early and frequent from day one

stakeholder_involvement.addie: Primarily at analysis and evaluation phases

best_for.sam: Unclear requirements, need speed, innovation valued
best_for.addie: Clear requirements, compliance needs, fixed scope

preparation.name: Preparation Phase
activities: Gather information about learners and context
preparation.deliverable: Project brief and initial design ideas

iterative_design.name: Iterative Design Phase
activities: Review with stakeholders in collaborative sessions
Refine design based on stakeholder input

savvy_start_workshop.description: Intensive collaborative design workshop that kicks off SAM projects
savvy_start_workshop.outcome: Aligned team with validated design direction and working prototypes

quality_progression.description: Quality improves with each iteration but with diminishing returns

iteration_1.descriptor: Initial rough draft, functional but unpolished

iteration_2.descriptor: Improved based on feedback, clearer direction

iteration_3.descriptor: More polished and effective, refined features

iteration_4.descriptor: Fine-tuned with user input, near production quality

iteration_5.descriptor: High-quality finished product, ready for deployment

common_pitfalls.solution: Schedule regular review sessions with all stakeholders
Set strict time limits and move to prototyping quickly
Define 'good enough' criteria upfront and stick to them
Make testing with real learners mandatory in each cycle
Invest in rapid prototyping tools and train team members

accessibility.described_content: Interactive SAM process visualizer showing three phases with spiral path, quality improvement tracking, and iterative progression through design and development cycles

learningObjectives: Understand the progression from raw data to actionable knowledge

Explain why connected information (knowledge graphs) provides more value than isolated facts

interactivity.description: Hover over any of the three triangle layers to display an informational tooltip explaining that layer's characteristics

visualElements.appearance: Black background with bright green 1s and 0s (terminal style)

visualElements.purpose: Represents isolated facts extracted from data

visualElements.appearance: Connected graph with nodes and edges in various colors
visualElements.purpose: Represents connected facts forming a knowledge graph

assumptions: Data volume decreases as semantic value increases moving up the triangle
Knowledge emerges from connections between information, not from isolated facts
Graph structure is the natural representation of the knowledge layer
simulationModel.pedagogicalPurpose: Help students understand why graph databases are valuable by visualizing how connected information (knowledge graphs) differs fundamentally from raw data and isolated facts

title: Minimum Spanning Tree Algorithm Visualizer
creator: Claude Code AI Assistant
subject: Computer Science
Graph Theory
Algorithms
Data Structures
description: Interactive visualization demonstrating Kruskal's and Prim's algorithms for finding minimum spanning trees in weighted graphs. Students can step through algorithm execution, compare approaches, and understand cycle detection in network optimization.
learningObjectives: Understand the minimum spanning tree problem and its applications
Compare Kruskal's edge-based and Prim's node-based algorithmic approaches
Analyze how greedy algorithms make locally optimal choices
Observe cycle detection mechanisms using union-find data structures
Apply graph theory concepts to real-world network optimization problems
prerequisites: Familiarity with greedy algorithms (helpful but not required)

accessibility.screenReader: ARIA labels provided via p5 describe() function
accessibility.colorblindSafe: High contrast colors used for edge states

controls.name: Algorithm Selection
controls.description: Choose between Kruskal's (edge-based) or Prim's (node-based) algorithm

controls.name: Step Forward
controls.description: Execute one algorithm step to observe decision-making process

controls.name: Auto Run
controls.description: Automatically animate complete algorithm execution

controls.name: Reset
controls.description: Generate new random graph and restart simulation

controls.name: Animation Speed
controls.description: Control delay between algorithm steps for learning pace

variables: nodes - graph vertices with positions and labels
edges - graph edges with weights and states
mstEdges - edges accepted into minimum spanning tree
parent - union-find structure for Kruskal's cycle detection
visited - node tracker for Prim's algorithm
priorityQueue - candidate edges for Prim's algorithm
equations: MST weight = sum of all accepted edge weights
Greedy choice: min(available edges satisfying constraints)
assumptions: Graph is connected (all nodes reachable from any starting node)
Edge weights are positive integers (50-200 range)
8 nodes with ~15 edges provides good visualization
Both algorithms always find an MST (may differ in edge selection order)
limitations: Does not handle disconnected graphs
Does not visualize internal data structures (union-find tree, priority queue)
Random graph generation may create varying difficulty levels
Cannot create custom graphs interactively
realWorldApplications: Supply chain and distribution network design

controls.name: temperatureSlider
controls.label: Temperature
controls.purpose: Adjust the temperature of the gas, affecting molecular speed and collision frequency

controls.label: Start Simulation / Pause Simulation
controls.purpose: Toggle simulation running state. Starts paused to allow users to set initial conditions before observing molecular motion.

controls.name: temperatureScale
controls.label: Temperature Scale
controls.purpose: Switch between Celsius and Fahrenheit temperature scales

displays.name: Wall Hits/sec
displays.purpose: Shows collision frequency as a direct indicator of gas pressure

displays.name: Ice/Fire Region
displays.purpose: Visual indicator showing ice cubes below 0°C and flames above 0°C

displays.name: Atom Colors
displays.purpose: Atoms change from blue (cold) to red (hot) based on temperature

simulation.modelType: Molecular dynamics - kinetic theory of gases

variables.name: temperature
variables.description: Temperature in Celsius (internally), affects molecular speed

variables.name: numAtoms
variables.description: Number of gas atoms in chamber (fixed)

variables.name: collisionsPerSecond
variables.description: Number of wall collisions per second (pressure indicator)

equations.name: Velocity-Temperature Relationship
equations.description: Molecular speed increases linearly with temperature

equations.name: Kinetic Energy
equations.description: Kinetic energy is proportional to absolute temperature

assumptions: Elastic collisions with walls (no energy loss)
No inter-molecular collisions modeled (simplified)
2D simulation of 3D phenomenon
Linear relationship between temperature and speed for educational clarity
Constant chamber volume
limitations: Does not model inter-molecular attractions (van der Waals forces)
Simplified pressure calculation (wall hits only, not force)
No modeling of phase changes beyond visual indicator
2D representation of 3D molecular motion
Does not account for relativistic effects at extreme speeds

Recognize why surface-level interventions often fail to create lasting change
Identify which leverage level is appropriate for different change strategies
Navigate to detailed explanations of each leverage point
educationalMetadata.prerequisites: Basic understanding of systems thinking concepts

accessibility.screenReader: Canvas description provided via describe() function
accessibility.colorContrast: High contrast text, zone colors distinguishable

controls.description: Hover over iceberg layers to see detailed information in the right panel
Click any layer to navigate to its detailed explanation in Chapter 6

visualElements.name: Iceberg
visualElements.description: Left side visualization showing 10 leverage point layers with animated waterline

visualElements.name: Info Panel
visualElements.description: Right side panel showing layer details on hover or introduction text by default

visualElements.name: Zone Legend
visualElements.description: Color-coded legend showing Shallow, Structural, Deep, and Transformative zones

assumptions: Leverage points are hierarchical with deeper points being more effective
The iceberg metaphor accurately represents visibility vs effectiveness tradeoff
limitations: Levels 2 and 3 are combined with Level 4 for simplicity
Actual effectiveness depends heavily on context and implementation
